id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc: Series name used for displaying in [tooltip](~tooltip) and filtering with [legend](~legend), or updating data and configuration with `setOption`.

zlevel.desc:
`zlevel` value of all graphical elements in .

`zlevel` is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different `zlevel` values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate `zlevel`. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash.

Canvases with bigger `zlevel` will be placed on Canvases with smaller `zlevel`.

z.desc:
`z` value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller `z` values may be overwritten by those with larger `z` values.

`z` has a lower priority to `zlevel`, and will not create new Canvas.

left.desc:
Distance between sankey component and the left side of the container.

`left` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`; and it can also be `'left'`, `'center'`, or `'right'`.

If the `left` value is set to be `'left'`, `'center'`, or `'right'`, then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

top.desc:
Distance between sankey component and the top side of the container.

`top` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`; and it can also be `'top'`, `'middle'`, or `'bottom'`.

If the `left` value is set to be `'top'`, `'middle'`, or `'bottom'`, then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

right.desc:
Distance between sankey component and the right side of the container.

`right` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`.

bottom.desc:
Distance between sankey component and the bottom side of the container.

`bottom` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`.

nodeWidth.desc: The node width of rectangle in Sankey diagram.

nodeGap.desc: The gap between any two rectangles in each column of the Sankey diagram.

nodeAlign.desc:
Controls the horizontal alignment of nodes in the diagram.

May be:

+ `left`: initial nodes (those with no incoming links) are aligned to the left of the diagram.

+ `right`: terminal nodes (those with no outgoing links) are aligned to the right of the diagram.

+ `justify`: initial and terminal nodes are aligned on the left and right edges.

Note when [orient](~series-sankey.orient) is `vertical`, `nodeAlign` controls vertical alignment.

layoutIterations.desc: The iterations of layout, which is used to iteratively optimize the position of the nodes and edges in the Sankey diagram to reduce the overlapping between nodes and edges. The default value is `32`. If you want the order of the nodes in the chart to be the same with the order in the original [data](~series-sankey.data), you can set the value to be `0`.

orient.desc: The layout direction of the nodes in the Sankey diagram, which can be horizontal from left to right or vertical from top to bottom. The corresponding parameter values ​​are `horizontal` or `vertical`.

draggable.desc: The drag-and-drop interaction of the node, which is enabled by default. After opening, the user can drag any node in the Sankey diagram to any position. To turn this interaction off, simply set the value to `false`.

levels.depth.desc: Specify which layer is set, value starts from 0.

levels.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

levels.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

levels.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

levels.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

levels.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

levels.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

levels.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

levels.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

levels.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

levels.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

levels.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

levels.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

levels.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

levels.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

levels.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

levels.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

levels.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

levels.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

levels.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

levels.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

levels.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

levels.itemStyle.borderType.desc:

+ `'dashed'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With

`borderType`

levels.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

levels.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

levels.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

levels.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

levels.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

levels.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

levels.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

levels.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

+ `'dotted'`

levels.emphasis.itemStyle.borderDashOffs.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

levels.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

levels.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

levels.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiterLim.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

levels.select.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

levels.select.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.

label.desc: `label` describes the text label style in each rectangular node.

label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`

For example：


label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

If hide the overlapped labels.

The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming.

~[600x400](graph-label-overlap&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping.

Currently supported configurations:

+ `'shiftX'` Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
+ `'shiftY'` Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use `moverOverlap: 'shiftY'` to place the labels aligned vertically.

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with `x`.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with `y`

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with `overflow` to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with `lineOverflow` to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be `'left'`, `'center'`, `'right'`.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be `'top'`, `'middle'`, `'bottom'`.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is:

```js
[[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
```

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

+ `'target'`: use target node color.

emphasis.focus.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`




When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported:

+ `'none'` Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
+ `'self'` Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.


+ `'series'` Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.



+ `'adjacency'` Focus on the elements of adjacent nodes and edges in the graph.



**Example: **


```js
emphasis: {
focus: 'series',
blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
}
```

~[600x400](bar-y-category-stack&reset=1&edit=1)

emphasis.blurScope.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



The range of fade out when `focus` is enabled. Support the following configurations

+ `'coordinateSystem'`
+ `'series'`
+ `'global'`

emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`

`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`



Configurations of selected state. Available when [selectedMode](~series-sankey.selectedMode) is set.

select.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

select.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

select.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

select.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

select.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:


data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeep.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.background.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWid.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHei.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

data.blur.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

data.blur.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

data.blur.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

data.blur.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

data.blur.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.blur.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.blur.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

data.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

data.blur.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

data.blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

data.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.blur.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since 5.2.0, it can be set to `'inherit'` in the `emphasis` state to disable color highlight.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

data.blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

data.blur.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.blur.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

data.blur.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

data.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.blur.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

data.blur.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.widt.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.select.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

data.select.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAs.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.backgroundCo.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.select.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.select.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.select.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeigh.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.

String template** The template variables are `{a}`, `{b}`, `{c}`, `{d}` and `{e}`, which stands for series name, data name and data value and ect. When [trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is set to be `'axis'`, there may be data from multiple series. In this time, series index can be refered as `{a0}`, `{a1}`, or `{a2}`. `{a}`, `{b}`, `{c}`, `{d}` have different meanings for different series types: + Line (area) charts, bar (column) charts, K charts: `{a}` for series name, `{b}` for category name, `{c}` for data value, `{d}` for none; + Scatter (bubble) charts: `{a}` for series name, `{b}` for data name, `{c}` for data value, `{d}` for none; + Map: `{a}` for series name, `{b}` for area name, `{c}` for merging data, `{d}` for none; + Pie charts, gauge charts, funnel charts: `{a}` for series name, `{b}` for data item name, `{c}` for data value, `{d}` for percentage. **Example: ** ```js formatter: '{b0}: {c0}
{b1}: {c1}' ``` **2. Callback function** The format of callback function: ```js (params: Object|Array, ticket: string, callback: (ticket: string, html: string)) => string | HTMLElement | HTMLElement[] ``` The first parameter `params` is the data that the formatter needs. Its format is shown as follows: ```js { componentType: 'series', // Series type seriesType: string, // Series index in option.series seriesIndex: number, // Series name seriesName: string, // Data name, or category name name: string, // Data index in input data array dataIndex: number, // Original data as input data: Object, // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data. // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar) value: number|Array|Object, // encoding info of coordinate system // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle') // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like: // { // x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis. // y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis. // } encode: Object, // dimension names list dimensionNames: Array, // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ... // Only work in `radar` series. dimensionIndex: number, // Color of data color: string, {{ for: as , }}{{ /for }} } ``` Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be: If data is: ```js dataset: { source: [ ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7], ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1], ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5], ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1] ] } ``` We can get values that corresponding to y axis by: ```js params.value[params.encode.y[0]] ``` If data is: ```js dataset: { dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'], source: [ {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7}, {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1}, {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5}, {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1} ] } ``` We can get values that corresponding to y axis by: ```js params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]] ``` When [trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'axis'`, or when tooltip is triggered by [axisPointer](~xAxis.axisPointer), `params` is the data array of multiple series. The content of each item of the array is the same as above. Besides, ```js { componentType: 'series', // Series type seriesType: string, // Series index in option.series seriesIndex: number, // Series name seriesName: string, // Data name, or category name name: string, // Data index in input data array dataIndex: number, // Original data as input data: Object, // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data. // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar) value: number|Array|Object, // encoding info of coordinate system // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle') // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like: // { // x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis. // y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis. // } encode: Object, // dimension names list dimensionNames: Array, // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ... // Only work in `radar` series. dimensionIndex: number, // Color of data color: string, {{ for: as , }}{{ /for }} } ``` Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be: If data is: ```js dataset: { source: [ ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7], ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1], ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5], ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1] ] } ``` We can get values that corresponding to y axis by: ```js params.value[params.encode.y[0]] ``` If data is: ```js dataset: { dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'], source: [ {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7}, {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1}, {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5}, {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1} ] } ``` We can get values that corresponding to y axis by: ```js params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]] ``` **Note: **Using array to present all the parameters in ECharts 2.x is not supported anymore. The second parameter `ticket` is the asynchronous callback flag which should be used along with the third parameter `callback` when it is used. The third parameter `callback` is asynchronous callback. When the content of tooltip is acquired asynchronously, `ticket` and `htm` as introduced above can be used to update tooltip with callback. Example: ```js formatter: function (params, ticket, callback) { $.get('detail?name=' + params.name, function (content) { callback(ticket, toHTML(content)); }); return 'Loading'; } ```

tooltip.backgroundColor.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The background color of tooltip's floating layer.

tooltip.borderColor.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The border color of tooltip's floating layer.

tooltip.borderWidth.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The border width of tooltip's floating layer.

tooltip.padding.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The floating layer of tooltip space around content. The unit is px. Default values for each position are 5. And they can be set to different values with left, right, top, and bottom. Examples: ```js // Set padding to be 5 padding: 5 // Set the top and bottom paddings to be 5, and left and right paddings to be 10 padding: [5, 10] // Set each of the four paddings seperately padding: [ 5, // up 10, // right 5, // down 10, // left ] ```

tooltip.textStyle.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The text syle of tooltip's floating layer.

tooltip.textStyle.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

tooltip.textStyle.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

tooltip.textStyle.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

tooltip.textStyle.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

tooltip.textStyle.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

tooltip.textStyle.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

tooltip.textStyle.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

tooltip.textStyle.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

tooltip.extraCssText.desc:
> **Notice：**series.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
Extra CSS style for floating layer. The following is an example for adding shadow. ```js extraCssText: 'box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);' ```
